entry.title: Considerations when implementing IAS for SuccessFactors Onboarding
entry.content:
In H2 2026 the username and password authentication process for onboarding will be deprecated and they will need to use IAS to log in.  In this article we will discuss various options to consider when implementing IAS for onboarding.  We will assume that IAS is already enabled for Employee Central.

Implementing IAS is quite simple for an onboarding perspective, a switch is enabled in provisioning and emails need to be adjusted.  All the logic in IAS should be built by an IAS consultant.

Emails

When IAS is enabled for onboarding the ‚Äòusername/password‚Äô is sent from IAS rather than from SuccessFactors.  I prefer to still send the ‚ÄòExternal Welcome email‚Äô from SuccessFactors Onboarding.  The welcome email explains that they will get a second email with the login credentials.  I prefer to send two emails as we can customize this email to a greater extent than the IAS email.  In the welcome email you will need to remove the password reset and username, and this will need to be removed for the rehire email as well.  The login link in the other emails will work with IAS.

To get two emails to be sent at the same time will require the real time synch in IAS.

The first email comes from SuccessFactors Onboarding.  This is the external email welcome template. 

The second email comes at the same time from IAS and will allow them to set their password to log in.

To log on they click on the link, and they set their password.

Once they have reset their password they should be redirect to the login page; to do this you will need to set up the redirect in IAS.

Once they have submitted their username and password you can choose to add a new layer of authentication.  Once way is to send a code to their email address.  You can also send this by SMS but this will require a third party provider.

Once they submit the code they will be able to log in.

Once they log in, they can proceed with onboarding as normal.

On their hire date the individual will not get a new IAS account but will be moved to an employee group and they will be able to log in with same IAS account that they used in onboarding.

If the Onboardee needs a new password then they have the ability to request a new password from the logic in screen, this comes from IAS.  If you need to manually reset a password then this needs to be done from IAS.

If you cancel onboarding they should be removed from IAS, but this will depend on the set up in IAS.  Please note there could be time delay for IAS to be updated.

Rehires

When an employee is terminated from Employee Central then their details are typically deleted from IAS, they can be made inactivated, but it is advised that they are deleted.  ips.delete.existedbefore.entities=true

When onboarding starts the onboardee receives an email as above.  When the rehire, check has been completed it follows the same process as without IAS, they get an new IAS email to go in that is linked to their inactive Employee Central Account.  As the old IAS account was deleted this is new IAS account but liked to the inactive user record.  Once they log in their can proceed with onboarding as normal.

When deploying IAS, it is imperative that the rehire process is fully tested.

Implementing IAS whilst live with Onboarding.

Some onboardees  will be using the old username and password method.  As you approach the deployment, we suggest the following.

  • About 2-3 weeks before go live update the welcome email so users know you are changing the authentication process, and they will get a new email to log in. 
  • Add this to a custom homepage tile, this is just there to prevent any concerns over phishing.
  • On go live day pause all initiation of onboarding
  • Update onboarding IAS email with text applicable to all onboardee who are currently in the process, explaining what they need to do.
  • Synch onboarding with IAS, once this is completed update onboarding IAS email with standard text
  • Restart onboarding initiation

entry.title: 02 SAP SuccessFactors HCM Implementation - Clean Core Guidelines
entry.content:
The purpose of this blog is to share Clean Core guidelines for SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation, based on my experience. This is not official SAP documentation or recommendation.

Clean Core is a key topic in SAP S/4HANA Transformation projects and must be adopted as part of the S/4HANA Journey. SAP has delivered tools, frameworks, and Strategy documents to support it, but I haven't seen much content for SAP SuccessFactors HCM projects. I hope this blog addresses this to some extent.

Why is a clean core essential in SAP SuccessFactors HCM?

 Clean Core is a set of guiding principles that support continuous business transformation by designing an agile, innovative, and efficient SAP SuccessFactors HCM system, reducing technical debt and manual effort, and adopting a framework for building a maintainable system that leverages standard capabilities wherever possible.

If you are using SAP ERP HCM as Core HR, the system has evolved over the years and is usually customized to support your business processes, Integrations, and reporting. There is a valid reason for customization, but it introduced long-term challenges, technical debt, and high maintenance costs, which are well known, and every customer raises concerns about them.

SAP SuccessFactors HCM Clean Core Guiding Principles: 

  1. Business Processes: Standardize processes (fit-to-standard) to increase efficiency and adapt to market shifts.
  2. Data: Maintain high-quality, consistent data and implement robust governance to improve reporting, Integration, and analytics.
  3. Integration: Use standard APIs (OData, Web Services, ISC), Packaged Integrations, Event Driven Architecture (EDA), and direct API-based integrations to avoid complex custom integrations and Data gaps.
  4. Operations and Upgrades: Manage the lifecycle, ensure efficient monitoring, and adopt the new features of the SAP SuccessFactors HCM system.
  5. Extensibility: Built customer-specific, unique requirements using Extension Center Objects and SAP BTP CAP extensibility using the OData APIs to decouple customizations from the core for upgrade stability and build UI experience using Fiori and implement workflow /automation capabilities using SAP Build.

Business Process Clean Core governance framework:

This is a high-level framework that you could enhance based on your project structure and governance model.

Recommendations for Implementing Clean Core Guiding Principles:

 

  1. SAP SuccessFactors HCM Product Capabilities: Understanding the product capabilities is key to implementing or adopting fit-to-standard clean core guidelines. If the implementation resource lacks SME-level experience, the solution will likely be suboptimal and will usually require significant customization. 2
  2. Guiding principles and standards for each work stream: Create guiding principles and leading practices for each work stream (Functional, Data, Integration, and Extensibility), and ensure the project implementation team, including the customer and SI resources, must follow them as part of implementation to produce outstanding results. 
  3. Skills resources from SI: Having skilled resources from SI (Solution Architect, Functional Leads, and Technical Architect) who are familiar with the clean core implementation is key. Ensuring they own the quality of the work is key and should be part of the statement of work. 
  4. Preferred success service: Preferred success customers -leverage SAP's preferred success services like solution launch checks and success checks to review the SF configuration, Design, Integration strategy, and Integration code during the implementation. 
  5. Review Implementation Design Principles (IDPs): Based on my experience, IDPs are key assets for clean core guidelines. They provide structured guidance for addressing challenging customer requirements and frequently asked questions during the design and implementation phases of a project.

https://pages.community.sap.com/topics/successfactors/implementation-design-principles#sap-successfactors-recruiting-management-and-employee-central-integration 

      6. SuccessFactors Architecture Leading Practice (ALP): ALP is another key asset for clear core guidelines, and it provides a set of recommended configuration decisions and guidance on topics associated with a SuccessFactors implementation, and a recommendation to drive positive outcomes aligned with the intended system design, leveraging proven success from previous deployments, and avoiding pitfalls.

 https://pages.community.sap.com/topics/successfactors/architecture-leading-practices

 7. Integrations: Integration is a common area where extensive customization is done, which adds technical debt and high maintenance costs. Make sure that the resources who built integrations have.

 Prior experience in building integrations for SAP SuccessFactors HCM.

  • Understanding of SAP SuccessFactors APIs leading practices and Integration tools.
  • Strong integration design skills .
  • Understanding of packaged integrations and capabilities.
  • Integration Center and SAP Integration Suite Capabilities, and when to use these tools for custom integrations. 

 8. Leverage standard capabilities to capture quality data: Implementing proper validation business rules and framework to capture data is key . 

9) Data retention and Purge Data: Setting up the proper data retention rules and purging unnecessary data based on your data retention requirements will help you maintain key data. 

10) Monitoring Tools:  Leverage standard capabilities offered by SAP SuccessFactors HCM Suite and SAP Solutions like Cloud ALM to monitor the jobs and schedules, which reduces system maintenance costs. 

11)Handling Product gaps: Some requirements will challenge the product capabilities, and they will be identified as gaps. Now, how you handle the product gaps is very key, based on my experience below,

  • Check if the functionality can be achieved using Extension Center Objects ( MDF). 
  • If MDF is not a solution, then check the Product roadmap to see if anything is planned in the upcoming releases. 
  • If Options 1 and 2 are not viable, then check if the partner has built any BTP Extension solutions in the App store. 
  • If a partner solution is not available, you can leverage the SAP BTP Extensibility Framework to extend SAP SuccessFactors and build the required functionality.

Commonly Asked Questions: 

 1)Creating custom fields and extension Center Objects is deviating from the clean core?

 No. But it is essential to check whether the functionality can be achieved using standard fields before using custom fields and the extension Center (MDF) object.

 2)How can I check if my SI is implementing and following clear core guidelines? 

Having the right skill resources for the project implementation is key. It is strongly recommended that key SI resources be validated before onboarding.

 3) What are the assets SAP has delivered for SI and Customers?

 I have used the following assets, and they have always helped.

  •  Implementation Design Principles covering all topics.
  • Architecture Leading Practices.
  • Process Maps.
  • Leading practices document.

  4)What are the areas that cause technical debt in SAP SuccessFactors HCM? 

Technical debt refers to the implied cost of future rework, Manual work, and maintenance resulting from choosing quick, short-term implementation or configuration solutions over more robust, long-term best practices. 

  • Integrations with External systems ‚Äì Building custom integrations with Poor Integration Design and coding standards
  • Manual workarounds and manual data maintenance processes
  • Customizations over Standard Functionality, Creating custom fields and MDF objects without governance.
  • Not ready to optimize business processes and build a solution that requires so much effort to maintain.
  • Not automating data imports.

5) Is optimizing business processes a must for a clean core?

 Yes. Optimizing some of the business processes is not possible due to various factors, which is reality, but as a customer having a mindset to optimize is very key, and checking the solution design options from the SI team and walking through with business and HR is always recommended.

entry.title: The Date Is Technically Correct‚Ä¶ but HR Is Still Not Happy
entry.content:
‚ÄúThe Date Is Technically Correct‚Ä¶ but HR Is Still Not Happy‚Äù

A Practical How-To for Resignation and Last Working Date Logic in SAP SuccessFactors EC

It usually starts with a resignation case that looks harmless.

The system shows a date.
Payroll confirms the calculation.
Technically, everything is correct.

And then HR says:

‚ÄúThis is not how resignations work in real life.‚Äù

If you‚Äôve implemented SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, you‚Äôve heard this before. Especially during UAT. Especially when exits, notice periods, and payroll deadlines are involved.

This how-to article explains how to fix one of the most common ‚Äî and most underestimated ‚Äî gaps in EC:
Date of Resignation and Last Working Date logic when time, weekends, and notice periods collide.

 

Why This Problem Shows Up in Almost Every EC Project

Out of the box, Employee Central treats dates exactly as dates.

  • A resignation submitted on Sunday is still Sunday
  • A resignation submitted at 6:31 PM is still ‚Äútoday‚Äù
  • A notice period end date can land on a weekend without any warning

From a system point of view, nothing is wrong.
From a business point of view, this causes confusion, rework, and manual overrides.

HR teams think in:

  • Working days
  • Office cut-off times
  • Payroll processing realities

This how-to focuses on aligning system logic with business reality.

 

Business Requirement (What We Are Solving)

Date of Resignation (DOR)

  • If an employee submits resignation after 6:30 PM IST, the system should consider the next working day as the effective Date of Resignation.
  • If an employee submits resignation on Saturday or Sunday, the system should automatically move the Date of Resignation to the first working day.

Last Working Date (LWD) as per Notice Period

  • LWD should be calculated as:
    Date of Resignation + Required Days of Notice (calendar days)
  • If the calculated LWD falls on a weekend, it should move to the next working day.

 

System Assumptions (Critical)

Before building the rules, confirm the following:

  • Module: SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central
  • System Locale: EN_US
  • Business Time Zone: IST
  • Working Days: Monday to Friday
  • Working Hours Cut-off: 18:30 IST
  • Notice Period Type: Calendar days

Even though the system locale is EN_US, resignation timing must follow IST working hours.
This detail is often missed ‚Äî and causes most after-hours issues.

 

Solution Design (Recommended Approach)

To keep the logic stable and easy to explain during UAT, the solution is split into two independent EC Business Rules:

  1. Date of Resignation Adjustment Rule
  2. Last Working Date as per Notice Period Rule

Each rule has a clear responsibility and does not interfere with the other.

 

Rule 1: Adjust Date of Resignation

(After Hours & Weekend Handling)

Purpose

Ensure the effective Date of Resignation always falls on a working day.

Rule Setup

  • Scenario: Trigger onChange Rules for HRIS Elements
  • Base Object: Employment Details
  • Execution: On Change
  • Field: Date of Resignation

Logic Overview

  1. Convert system DateTime to IST using UTC offset (5.5).
  2. If time is on or after 18:30 IST, shift DOR to the next day.
  3. Check day of week:
    • Saturday ‚Üí add 2 days
    • Sunday ‚Üí add 1 day

Outcome

The system stores a business-valid Date of Resignation, not just the submission date.

 

 

Rule 2: Calculate Last Working Date as per Notice Period

Purpose

Calculate LWD correctly and prevent it from falling on a weekend.

Rule Setup

  • Scenario: Trigger onChange Rules for HRIS Elements
  • Base Object: Employment Details
  • Execution: On Change
  • Trigger Fields:
    • Date of Resignation
    • Required Days of Notice

Step 1: Provisional LWD

Provisional LWD = Date of Resignation + Required Days of Notice

This uses calendar days, as defined by policy.

Step 2: Weekend Validation

  • Saturday ‚Üí add 2 days
  • Sunday ‚Üí add 1 day
  • Weekday ‚Üí no change

Outcome

The final Last Working Date as per Notice Period always lands on a working day.

 

 

 

 

Important Detail: How Notice Period Is Counted

This is where most confusion happens.

In SuccessFactors:

  • When you add calendar days, the Date of Resignation is already included.

Example

  • Effective Date of Resignation: 15-Dec-2025
  • Required Days of Notice: 45

Correct system result:

  • Last Working Date = 28-Jan-2026

Adding one extra day here would be incorrect.

 

End-to-End Test Scenario

Input

  • Date of Resignation entered: 14-Dec-2025 (Sunday)
  • Required Days of Notice: 45
  • Submission time: After 6:30 PM IST

System Result

  1. Effective DOR ‚Üí 15-Dec-2025 (Monday)
  2. Provisional LWD ‚Üí 28-Jan-2026
  3. Weekend check ‚Üí Not required

Final Values

  • Date of Resignation: 15-Dec-2025
  • Last Working Date as per NP: 28-Jan-2026

 

 

Rule Assignment Summary

Rule

Field

Execution

DOR Adjustment Rule

Date of Resignation

On Change

LWD Calculation Rule

Last Working Date as per NP

On Change

This sequencing avoids circular updates and ensures consistent behaviour.

 

Key Takeaways

  • Normalize Date of Resignation first
  • Separate resignation timing logic from notice period logic
  • EN_US locale does not imply US working hours
  • Weekend handling must be explicit in EC
  • Small date errors create big HR trust issues

 

Closing Note

Resignation logic is one of those areas where the system is judged not by its features, but by its judgment.

When dates behave the way HR expects, no one notices.
When they don‚Äôt, everyone does.

Getting this right is less about complex configuration and more about understanding how business actually works.

entry.title: 03 SAP SuccessFactors HCM Implementation - Phase 0 - Customer Readiness and ownership
entry.content:
This blog walks through the key areas customers should focus on, along with the ownership plan for the SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation. In my previous post, I covered the objectives of Phase 0; this article continues the series by turning the focus to customer readiness.

https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-blog-posts-by-sap/01-sap-successfactors-hcm-implementation-phase-0-objectives/ba-p/14287328

Customer readiness is essential to the success of an SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation. The following are key items customers should plan for as part of Phase 0.

  1. Execution ownership
  2. Project Business Outcome and Goals
  3. Enterprise Architectural Strategy and Infrastructure Readiness
  4. Business and HR Ownership
  5. Data Migration Workstream ownership
  6. Technical Integration Workstream
  7. Testing Strategy and execution
  8.  Training and Sustainment
  9.  Resource Allocation and Planning

1. Ownership of the project execution.

This is a critical decision for customers: should the system integrator (SI) lead the implementation, or should the customer take the lead? Customer-led projects tend to offer greater transparency at every stage, making it easier to identify risks early and address them effectively. That said, customers must realistically assess whether they have the internal resources and capabilities to manage the project in this way.

What is a customer lead project?

Each workstream within the project has an assigned owner accountable for execution, supported by the system integrator (SI). The customer Business and HR teams lead the initiative, while the SI contributes SuccessFactors SMEs and consultants to deliver the required work.

2) Define and Align Project Business Outcomes and Goals

 Defining project business outcomes and effectively communicating them to the project team are critical steps. As part of this process,

  • Define HR Strategy and Goals: Clearly articulate the specific HR challenges to be addressed and set measurable objectives (e.g., reduce time-to-hire, increase employee engagement, automate manual tasks, adopt SAP Business AI, integrate better with ERP systems, provide better reporting, etc) and make sure that SI is aligned.
  • Establish Project Governance: Define the project team structure, decision-making processes, roles, and responsibilities (for both the customer and the implementation partner/SI).
  • Implementation Approach: Determine the deployment strategy, including which modules will be implemented
  • Current State Analysis & Process Mapping: Documenting existing HR processes ("As-Is") to understand current pain points and identify simplification opportunities.
  • Future State Vision: Begin defining the "To-Be" processes, aligning them with SAP SuccessFactors HCM leading practices and the "clean core" mindset.

3. Enterprise Architecture Stagey and Infrastructure Readiness  

 HR data is used by many internal and external applications, so implementing SAP SuccessFactors HCM requires thinking beyond just HR. From an enterprise architecture and infrastructure perspective, customers should involve enterprise and solution architects to assess the impact on the technology stack, help align the project with the overall technology architecture, and ensure that architecture, design, and adoption stay aligned with the broader strategy.

  • Define Clean Core guidelines  ‚ÄìEnsure the SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation follows the clean core strategy and standardized (Fit-to-Standard approach), and focus on reducing technical debt and manual work.

         Check the blog below for clean core guidelines for SAP SuccessFactors HCM.

https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-blog-posts-by-sap/02-sap-successfactors-hcm-implementation-clean-core-guidelines/ba-p/14289052

  • SAP BTP as the Innovation Layer: SAP Integration Suite is usually used as the middleware layer, and SAP BTP is leveraged for building or enhancing capabilities. Make sure you have a clear strategy in place. If you‚Äôre already using SAP BTP for SAP S/4HANA or other SAP solutions, ensure that your SuccessFactors implementation follows the same guidelines and aligns with your overall strategy.
  • Data & Analytics: Utilize SAP BDC  on BTP for centralized, governed data insights and build a data lake platform. If you already have a Data platform like Snowflake, Databricks, KAFKA, etc. Have a staged approach to data sync and reporting.
  • SAP Business AI: Aligned with the organization‚Äôs AI adoption strategy, formulate a plan for implementing SAP Business AI for HCM. While SAP has prebuilt agentic use cases, any development of additional Joule skills and agents should follow a well-defined strategy to identify business cases and design effective automation solutions. 
  • Identity management and Security: Implement SAP Cloud Identity Services for central access governance across all cloud components.
  • Infrastructure Assessment: Ensure the necessary IT infrastructure and validation of new tools if they meet organization standards, Security( SAP IAS, SAP BTP/SF SLAs, SAP Cloud connector, Edge Integration Cell etc.)                                                          

4. Business and HR Ownership, Module Leads

Clear lines of accountability are essential to ensure the implementation meets business requirements and is adopted effectively. A designated workstream (module) lead should be identified for each SAP SuccessFactors HCM module, including Integration, Testing, and Data Migration. Each module lead will act as the primary point of contact for their assigned scope.

  • Module leads play a critical role and work closely with SI leads to conduct Fit-to-Standard workshops.
  • Validate solution design and manage module configuration, master data readiness, and security and authorizations within the module.
  • Ensure alignment between the module configuration and the approved Global Process Design (GPO sign-off).
  • Lead Unit Testing and support business users during Integration Testing (IT) and User Acceptance Testing (UAT).
  • Select workstream leads strategically, ensuring their current role and expertise are appropriate to lead the workstream.

 

Responsibility Area

Owner

Key Activities

Business/HR Ownership

Senior Business/HR Sponsors & Process Owners

Ultimate accountability for successful adoption, realization of benefits, and validating the final solution design.

Current Business Process Review (AS-IS)

Process Owners & Module Leads

Detailed documentation and analysis of existing processes to identify pain points, regulatory constraints, and non-value-add steps.

Design Ownership (TO-BE)

Global Process Owners (GPOs) & Solution Architects

Defines the standardized, future-state processes. Approves all deviations from standard  functionality (Fit-Gap analysis).

Data Ownership

Data Lead & Functional Owners

Responsible for data quality, migration mapping, cleaning, validation of data, and ongoing data governance in the new system.

 5. Data Migration Workstream ownership 

Data migration is a critical activity requiring substantial effort and resources. The customer, having comprehensive knowledge of existing data, should take the lead in the data workstream, overseeing all migration activities in coordination with the SI. 

  • Collaborate with SI resources to develop a comprehensive Data Migration Strategy.
  • Oversee and coordinate data migration activities, encompassing extraction, transformation, and loading.
  • Establish data quality standards and implement data cleansing processes in legacy systems before migration.
  • Identify all relevant data sources.
  • Define a robust data validation strategy to ensure integrity.
  • Develop and implement a data scrambling strategy to safeguard sensitive information.

6. Technical Integration Workstream 

Technical integration demands substantial effort. While the SI may develop the integrations, the customer is responsible for providing requirements, coordinating with application owners to assess impacts, and supporting interface testing, among other related tasks. 

  • Develop a current state integration inventory, review it with the SI team, and produce a final draft of integrations required for the future state.
  • Establish integration patterns aligned with the anticipated future scope.
  • Define a comprehensive integration strategy.
  • Validate SAP Integration Suite and SAP SuccessFactors Integration Center tools to ensure consistency with the overall integration strategy.
  • Identify legacy systems to be replaced and those to be retained.
  • Determine and implement a communication plan with vendors.
  • Prepare detailed integration requirement documents for all integrations in scope.
  • Design the future state technical landscape in collaboration with the SI team.                                                                                              

7. Testing Strategy and execution

Develop a well-defined testing strategy and designate accountability. Comprehensive testing is essential to mitigate post-go-live disruptions and enhance overall satisfaction with the SAP SuccessFactors HCM solution.

  • Define Ownership of Testing strategy and execution.
  • Resource availability to create test scenarios for all modules and integrations.
  • Tools to use for Testing( Automation Testing, Manual Testing)
  • Define clear target goals for each test cycle (SIT,UAT, End Testing, Payroll Parallel)
  • Even though using Automation Tools reduces manual testing efforts, manual testing is still required to validate some of the process that requires a good number of resources from the business / Testing, and Integration team.
  • Map all your test scenarios to business requirements, processes etc. Each Test scenario must represent a traceable requirement.

8. Training and Sustainability Strategy:

The success of an SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation depends heavily on user adoption and the system‚Äôs continued relevance. Ensure that all users‚Äîincluding employees, managers, HR, and system administrators‚Äîare proficient with the platform, and that the system remains optimized and aligned with evolving business needs well beyond the initial go-live..

  • Make sure module leads and business/HR teams get training at the start of the project‚Äîit will help them validate the solution design and understand future processes.
  • SAP Learning Hub is a great resource for the team to build their knowledge.
  • Get hands-on access to the SuccessFactors system and get comfortable using it.
  • Use WalkMe to help guide users and support learning in the system.                                                                                                 

9. Resource Allocation and Planning:

Precise forecasting of customer resource availability and required time commitment is essential to project success. At the conclusion of Phase 0, the customer must have a comprehensive resource plan and allocation details to ensure appropriate staffing during the implementation phase.

PS: The blog post content is based solely on my experience leading multiple SAP Global rollouts.

entry.title: Ensuring Accurate Auto Delegation in SuccessFactors Using Validation Rules
entry.content:
Introduction

I received a requirement from one of our clients asking if we can setup a guardrail which prevents delegators from assigning Delegates outside their Department. This requirement is very valid because delegates outside the home department will not be aware of the operations in the home Department, so there's no point in assigning the workflows to someone who is not aware of the process which could result in trouble for both the business and delegates. Immediately, I got in to action referring to the Auto Delegation Config Object and Set up a Guardrail which solved the Purpose!

How This Was Achieved Using Business Rules

Technical Architecture

Step 1: Access the Auto Delegation Config Object

Navigate to Configure Object Definitions, search for Auto Delegation Config, and open the object. This Generic object is the foundation for storing auto-delegation setup information and the details related to it (Auto-Delegate Config Details).This is where the Guardrails should be Set up.

Step 2: Create and Assign a On Save Business Rule

Next, create a on Save Business Rule that validates the delegate‚Äôs department against the delegator‚Äôs department. The rule checks whether both Employees belong to the same department. If not, the system triggers a validation error and prevents the record from being saved.


This rule can be customized further to include alternative or additional criteria depending on business needs.

Step 3: Configure Auto Delegation Using the Quick Action

Once the rule is assigned under the On Save rules of the Auto Delegation Config object, users can proceed to set up their auto-delegation via the Quick Action available on the SuccessFactors home page. The validation will run during the On-Save Action every time a delegator attempts to assign a delegate and validates the Delegator Department against the Delegatee Department

Conclusion

Guardrails always prevent and handle unforeseen scenarios. This guardrail here configured to validate department helps businesses maintain operational efficiency and keeps the business workflow moving intact!

Business Rules are the Core Engine behing SAP SuccessFactors and there's so much that can be done with Business Rules! Keep Exploring and Share how this has helped with your Organization!
